section.heading: Scope.
section.text: These regulations are designed to govern all self-insurers in the State, except the federal government and the State government unless otherwise provided.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Administration” means the Motor Vehicle Administration.
“Class A self-insurer” means:
A person or business, except taxicab operations, leasing or rental companies, and governmental entities; or
An interstate trucking company in whose name less than 26 vehicles are registered as owner or lessee in this State, but which has a fleet of 26 or more registered vehicles.
“Class B self-insurer” means a Maryland taxicab company.
“Class C self-insurer” means:
A public utility;
A quasigovernmental agency, including a public entity as defined in Article 48A, §482B(a), Annotated Code of Maryland; or
A local government.
“Class D self-insurer” means a person in the business of leasing or renting vehicles.
“Temporary substitute vehicle” means a vehicle acquired to temporarily replace a vehicle which is out of service.

section.heading: Conditions for Certification as a Self-Insurer.

para.text: An applicant for certification as a self-insurer shall:
Provide the same benefits required by Transportation Article, Title 17, Annotated Code of Maryland, and by a political subdivision, regulatory agency, or commission which regulates the self-insurer;
File an application for Maryland self-insurance annually accompanied by:
A nonrefundable actuarial fee as set forth in COMAR 11.11.05;
A security of a type and amount acceptable to the Administration;
A listing of vehicles that includes for each vehicle the:
Make;
Model;
Year;
Vehicle identification number;
Tag number; and
Title number; and
Reviewed financial statements for the past 3 years prepared by a certified public accountant;
Own or lease 26 or more vehicles directly or by an association approved by the Administration;
Open its books and records to the Administration for audit and inspection as requested during normal business hours;
Notify the Administration within 30 days of any material changes in management or of substantial financial changes having a negative effect on the applicant's net worth;
Comply with applicable fair claim settlement practice regulations as set forth by the Maryland Insurance Administration in COMAR 31.15.07.03;
Comply with all applicable rules and regulations as set forth by the Public Service Commission or the local jurisdiction;

Upon demand, furnish to the Administration an audit of claims and reserves prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting practices by an independent auditing firm or by the Administration at the expense of the Administration;
Notify the Administration within 21 days of any transfer of a vehicle being transferred in or out of the self-insurance program; and

File with the Administration, on forms approved by the Administration, accurate information on the permit holder, vehicle owner, and association to which they belong for each vehicle in the self-insurance program.

A replacement or newly acquired vehicle, as those terms are defined in the industry, or a temporary substitute vehicle as defined in Regulation .02 of this chapter, shall automatically be covered under the self-insurance agreement.
Each self-insurance certification expires annually on January 31.
The Administration may require a deposit of:
Money;
An irrevocable letter of credit;
Other securities as may be appropriate; or
A surety bond, in a form and amount determined by the Administration as sufficient, to provide protection to the public.

An irrevocable letter of credit or a surety bond filed with the Administration shall include a provision that the Administration will receive notice of cancellation at least 30 days before the cancellation date.
Money, Securities, or Surety Bond.
A deposit of money or securities may be used by the Administrator for outstanding unpaid final judgments against the named self-insured, within statutory limits.

A deposit of money, securities, or a surety bond may be released only if the Administration is satisfied that all claims have been satisfied and that the applicable statutes of limitation have expired.
The minimum security for self-insurance certification required for each class of self-insurer is, for:
Class A, security in the amount of $250,000;
Class B, a dedicated claim reserve fund with a minimum balance of $250,000 and irrevocable letters of credit for $100,000 increased each year for 5 years, as shown below:

tr.th: Letter of Credit or Surety Bond

tr.td: $30,000 the first year and $15,000 each year for years 2—5,
$50,000 the first year and $25,000 each year for years 2—5,
$70,000 the first year and $35,000 each year for years 2—5,
$100,000 the first year and $50,000 each year for years 2—5,
$130,000 the first year and $65,000 each year for years 2—5;

para.text: Class C, a letter of guarantee that any valid claims will be paid, signed by the chief executive and chief financial officers, or, in the case of a local government, the top elected official and the comptroller; and
Class D, acceptable security in the amount of:
$250,000, with an excess or reinsurance policy acceptable to the Administration.
The letters of credit required in §D(2) of this regulation shall:
Be issued January 1 of each year,
Be received by January 1 of each year,
Be payable on demand to the Motor Vehicle Administration upon presentation of a final judgment against the named self-insured, within statutory limits, that remains unsatisfied, and

Remain in effect for a period of 3 years after termination of self-insured status to cover claims that may be filed within the statutes of limitation, unless superseded by a bond or other evidence of financial security satisfactory to the Administration.

section.heading: Grounds for Denial, Suspension, or Revocation.
section.text: The self-insurance certificate of any self-insured may be suspended, cancelled, denied, or not renewed, after reasonable notice and opportunity to be heard, for the following reasons:

para.text: Failing to maintain:
The security or bond required by the Administration,
The dedicated claim reserve fund as established in Regulation .04 of this chapter,
An adequate dollar reserve fund for open claims, or
The information as set forth in the application and sworn to by the applicants;
Committing an unfair claim settlement practice as set forth in COMAR 31.15.07.03, when relevant and applicable as determined by the Administration;
Failing to:
Make claim files available for inspection by authorized Administration personnel under Regulation .03A(4) of this chapter,
Release information regarding open or closed claims to an authorized representative of the Administration,
Respond to claimants and adjust claims in a timely manner, consistent with general automobile insurance industry standards,
Cooperate in an audit or investigation conducted by Administration personnel during an audit of the self-insured's records or financial status, or
Maintain proper proportional registration when applicable;

A determination by the Administration that the self-insured is financially insolvent or that the appropriate security levels have decreased to the point that the Administration determines there may be a diminishing level of protection afforded;

Knowingly allowing anyone to operate or to attempt to operate, or failing to take adequate precautions to reasonably limit access to operate, a vehicle insured under a self-insurance program in an unlawful manner or by a person not qualified to do so under the laws of Maryland.
Appeals of decisions related to the self-insurance program shall be submitted in writing to the Self-Insurance Program Manager, by registered or certified mail.
A hearing on a contested decision of the Self-Insurance Program Manager shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures in COMAR 11.11.02.

Correspondence, notifications, and inquiries pertaining to this chapter shall be addressed to the Manager, Self-Insurance Program, Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration, 6601 Ritchie Highway, N.E., Glen Burnie, MD 21062.
Notifications regarding security expirations, cancellations, or terminations shall be sent by certified mail, and shall contain the name and certificate number of the self-insured.
For the purposes of this regulation, self-insurers include:
The State Government;
Class A self-insurers;
Class B self-insurers;
Class C self-insurers; and
Class D self-insurers.

Upon approval in the program, or a change in the self-insurer’s third-party administrator or third party-adjuster, each self-insurer shall provide the Administration the self-insurer’s third-party administrator’s or third-party adjuster’s:
Name;
Address; and
Telephone number.
The Administration shall provide to self-insurers, in a format determined by the Administration, self-insurance certification for each vehicle upon:
Initial registration into the program;
Renewal; and
Additions to the self-insurer’s vehicle fleet.
The self-insurer’s insurance card shall include the self-insurer’s:
Name;
Address;
Certificate number;
Self-insurer’s third-party administrator’s or third-party adjuster’s:
Name;
Address;
Telephone number;
Vehicle identification number; and
Any other relevant information.
Each self-insurer shall maintain, in each self-insured vehicle:
A self-insurance card; or
Evidence of self-insurance containing the information required by §D of this regulation, in a format approved by the Administration.

Each self-insurer shall have a 60-day grace period for newly acquired vehicles or vehicles for which there has been a change of self-insurer, allowing time for the Administration to provide the self-insurance card. During that time, for proof of self-insurance, the self-insurers shall maintain a copy of the self-insurer’s certificate in the vehicle.
